posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked:
Currently, my team has a vision system using two Limelight 3Gs to align to branches of the reef, and it works very well. To select which branch and face to align to, the driver uses the A, B, X, Y, LB, and RB buttons to select the face, and the LT and RT buttons to select the left or right branch respectively. Through a combination of these buttons and using the pathplanner library, our robot can align to any branch quickly.

However, in the heat of a match, it is common for the driver to make mistakes and go to the wrong branch, losing time and cycles in the process. My question for the programmers out there is how we can make this process more intuitive for the driver to maximize our scoring potential? TIA

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
This setup has worked well for us. It automatically aligns with the side you are closest to which removes the need for several buttons.

4915 PathPlanner Auto Align Whitepaper CD-Media: Papers
We use our odometry pose to calculate the closest reef face based off of the tag map and then use bumpers (lb/rb) for left/right

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We built a system where the operator (driver 2) chose the reef branch to target (branch 1-12 and level) with a macro keyboard with a rotary dial and three-keys for level .

These were then displayed on the dashboard (for confirmation) and the robot “auto-pilot” could align to them.

The operator has plenty of time in our long cycles (but also plenty of time on even a 5-6 second cycle) to make these inputs.

Submitted only as another possible approach; I think the “keep everything with a single driver and make the code help them” approach is superior in many ways, but this one is easy to be certain that you can implement it in a single day.

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked: We have the two buttons of the driver controller tied to aligning to the left and right branch (field relative) of each reef side! And then the reef side is whichever one the robot is closest to

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
We run a system inspired by how 6328 was doing it, we essentially weight each alignment position based on both distance, but also the difference between the translation vector between the robot and the alignment position, and the controller angle (so comparing where the robot would drive to where the driver is trying to go). We then also have both driver input and automatic input running constantly (well, if the robot has a coral and we’re relatively close to the reef), we scale how much the robot has control and how much the driver has control based on both distance to alignment goal and how the magnitude of the drive controller (pushing it further → more control for me, nudging it a bit → more control for robot)

This approach definitely has flaws and our implementation (its on github but the code is messy) could use some is tuning, however overall it works pretty well and rarely aligns to the wrong position, if it does its also easy to correct with the joystick, and if alignment isnt perfect im also able to correct for it with the joysticks still.

posts.name: Luke
posts.cooked: We also determine which face of the reef is closest and then use bumpers to choose left or right.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: I programmed a custom dashboard that operator holds on a tablet, and selects the level and if it is left/A/right. other than that, reef side is where the robot is closest to.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
We have two buttons for left and right on the driver’s joystick, then drive to the face with the closest tag using global fused pose.

The nearest function on Pose2d, as well as AprilTagFieldLayout will help with this.

posts.name: Miles
posts.cooked: Super low tech, we just pick whichever tag the front center camera can see best. Then we add a left right offset button on the controller to toggle between reef branches.

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked:
We bought a programmable keyboard and made a 4x4 key circle with the middle keys removed. This leaves enough keys for the 12 branches roughly on the same position as seen on the field. The driver first presses the level they want to score on and then chooses the branch individually with a single click.

Having the buttons labeled with the branch letters and the drivers memorizing the branch names makes it very hard to miss.
Several good concepts presented in this thread . Not sure how many were implemented.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked: We have a similar physical button board a student cooked up early on using a Raspberry Pi Zero and these Adafruit snap-apart NeoKeys .

link_counts.title: NeoKey 5x6 Ortho Snap-Apart Mechanical Key Switches w/ NeoPixel [For MX Compatible Switches] : ID 5157 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
Closest lineup position to the robot when the button is pressed. Pretty minimal load on the driver, they just drive near an available spot and press the button. They can add additional input or override if it goes the wrong way. It gets it 95%+ so mostly the driver just drives near, hits the button and watches to make sure it doesn’t do anything weird.

The level is set any time during the match with an up/down button. Since we tend to be working on 1 level at a time. So it just stays targeting that same level until the driver changes it.
Ive mentioned it a few times, but we use a touchscreen monitor running a custom app which allows me to select where our driver should score. Its been great for us this season (and got us an award).
